Bengaluru

Bengaluru, Nov. 8 -- Amazon.com Inc. has infused Rs.1,000 crore into Amazon Pay, the digital payments and financial services unit of Amazon India, amid an intensifying battle with Walmart-owned Flipkart in India's booming online retail market.

Singapore-based Amazon Corporate Holdings Pvt. Ltd has infused close to Rs.999.90 crore in Amazon Pay as part of the fundraise, while Mauritius-based Amazon.com Inc. Ltd infused another Rs.9.99 lakh into the payments unit, showed regulatory filings with the corporate affairs ministry and accessed by business intelligence platform Tofler.

Amazon Corporate Holdings received 999 million shares and Amazon.com incs another 99,920 shares at a nominal value of Rs.10 per share.

The latest fundraise follows Amazon Pay raising Rs.450 crore ahead of the Diwali season sales from its US parent to compete with Flipkart during the month-long festive season sales. Those funds were also raised by Amazon Corporate Holdings and Amazon.com Inc.

Mint reported in September that Amazon Pay hit 50 million users in India, leveraging unified payments interface (UPI) on its platform.

According to the company, customers were using the Amazon app to pay at 20 million local shops using the UPI quick response (QR) code. Further, more than 75% of its customers during the past one year came from tier-2 and 3 cities, it said.

"Our mission is to make paying for anything trusted, convenient and rewarding. We are excited by the rapid adoption of UPI, which now enables customers to do much more with their Amazon app beyond shopping. We are humbled to serve millions of our customers and merchants through UPI and play a key role in accelerating the government's vision of a less-cash India," Mahendra Nerurkar, chief executive officer and vice-president of Amazon Pay, had said in September.

In March, Amazon Technologies Inc., part of Amazon.com, acquired retail tech startup Perpule in an all cash-deal worth Rs.107.6 crore to bolster its play in the kirana-tech space, according to regulatory filings.

With this acquisition, the e-commerce giant was planning to ramp up its presence in the kirana-tech space and leverage Perpule's cloud-based point-of-sale (PoS) offering 'UltraPoS' to offer a new suite of technology products to kirana partners.

Along with the investment, Amazon Pay (India) Pvt. Ltd also reported its financials for the fiscal year ending 31 March 2021 (FY21).

The company clocked Rs.1,769 crore in overall revenues for FY21. This is a 22% increase from the previous fiscal (FY20) when the company had recorded Rs.1,370 crore in total income.

The company also narrowed its loss to Rs.1,516 crore in FY21 from Rs.1,868 crore in FY20.

Total expenses for the company stood at Rs.3,285 crore in FY21, a marginal decrease from FY20.

Over the past few years, Amazon Pay has ramped up its presence in the financial services space and currently offers car and bike insurance, digital gold as well as a digital credit card in partnership with ICICI Bank.

Recently, Amazon Pay also announced a long-term partnership with MakeMyTrip India, a fully owned subsidiary of MakeMyTrip Ltd, to offer travel services on Amazon.in.
